```{r}
#1. If X is a binomial random variable with expected value 6 and variance 2.4, use R to find P{X=4}.
dbinom(4,6,0.2)
#Variance=np(1-p)
#=6p(1-p)
#P=-1/5 (??), thus, 0.2
#or dbinom(4,1.66,3.6)

#or,
dbinom(4,10,.6)
#mean=6
#p=.6
#n=10





```


```{r}
#2. If X is normal random variable with expected value 10 and variance 36, use R to find: 
#(a) P{X<20} (6 points)
#mean: 10
pnorm(20,10,6,lower.tail = FALSE)
#or
dnorm(20,10,6,log = FALSE)

#(b) P{4<X<16} (8 points)
pnorm(4,10,6,lower.tail = TRUE)-pnorm(16,10,6,lower.tail = TRUE)
```
